page.title: 09Conservation in Ringland
page.content: The owner of{Taverham Hall Farm has kept most of the field boundaries and has repaired farm buildings rather than replace them. They have entered a competition for conservation and have high hopes of winning both locally and nationally. Half the estate is farmed, the rest is woodland & marsh. If trees die they are replaced. When crops need spraying he uses special sprays. A bee keeper has to remove his bees from the oil seed rape before it is sprayed. This is a relatively unspoilt area The river and disused gravel pits home many water birds. Flocks of geese eat on water meadows. In woods shy birds like the hawfinch live.The nightingale returns in far less numbers than once. One old local remembers when they were shot because of their 'infernal din.' Roe deer and foxes have been sighted. Otter have been hunted in the past.
